That way, the DOM gets a good deal fewer elements and longer threads can be shown without performance impact
Also, it would probably greatly reduce the load on Gravatar, because every time you do a new line now, it creates a new image which makes a new call - and not all of them are cached.

I have noticed this because sometimes I write a new line and my message shows up but it has to wait a blink of an eye to also load in the image—even though there are 20 occurrences of my image in the page already.
Should be, but as I've noticed, isn't always.
Also, another thing: if they ever switch over to using history management and pushState, then not having a ton of IMG elements to nullify would be a HUGE boon.

Right now, if they were to add history management to the site to prevent new page loads when navigating and only push in the new content, they'd have to manually nullify each IMG object to minimize memory impact. Not the case if you use CSS and classes w/background images.
(though that might still require you to nullify each unique image just the one time, I've not experimented with that yet so I've no idea how well browsers manage that in memory)
